title: How I Built My Dream Studio in San Francisco

rawLines.text: We did it. We have completed the Vibe
Studio. This right here is my dream
studio and I'm building it or we built
it in San Francisco and we're building
it within my dream company. Few months
ago, 4 months ago, I moved to San
Francisco. I've been sleeping on the
floor. It's great. It's fun. We're
having a good time. Uh we raised a bunch

want to spend this money to grow the
company? And one of those initiatives is
to build the Vive Studio. And the Vive
Studio is a mixture of hardware.
Obviously, we have camera one, two, and
camera three. You also have a big
display. You can't see it, but uh if you
look right here, I can actually control
my screen. And so, if I had three people

our screen at the same time. And if we
wanted to create a video where we're all
like three, like we compete against each
other to see who can vibe code the
coolest app. I think that style of video
is really fun. And so I wanted to create
a podcast studio that is both high
quality and it has the flexibility to do
a lot of screen sharing. Why did I want
to do screen sharing? Well, the biggest
inspiration I don't think people would
be surprised by this is Greg Eisenberg.
So Greg Eisenberg has the Startup Ideas
podcast and it is one of the fastest
growing podcasts in business or at least
it was last year. I'm not familiar with
how fast it's growing now, but I will
say it is a new phenomenon and it is
something that I'm calling a demo cast.
I think people are a little bit bored
and tired of listening to people talk in
podcasts. Maybe they're not tired of it
because the podcast market is growing so
fast and less and less people are making
podcasts, right? The growth rate of
people who are making podcasts is
actually going down. Meanwhile, the
amount of eyeballs on podcasts are going
up. The appetite for long- form content
is there. It's just it's very winner
take all. It's not like short form where
anyone can go viral. A lot of the people
who are into podcasts watch and listen
to the same podcasts. And I say watch
because they're becoming more visual. If
you look at the long- form trends,
right? people are watching YouTube
videos on their TV and it's becoming a
replacement for Netflix and I think
that's very interesting and so I think
we're seeing a rise of like more visual
podcasts and people are getting tired of
like the same pseudo philosophical Chris
Williamson style podcasts where they
just kind of like talk about philosophy
but not like really and I think people
want tactical strategies to learn how to
use specific tools and actually learn
right they don't want to just listen to
two people talk about how AI is changing

cast, right? I call it that. I don't

almost like collaborative tutorials. And
I wanted to do the same except I am in a

they all are interested in making
content. They just don't want to do all

like making the hooks really good,
making sure the edits are very solid.
And if we can build a team, right, if we

then we can grow rapidly and we can

We did it.
We have completed the Vibe Studio.
This right here is my dream studio, and I'm building it, or we built it in San Francisco, and we're building it within my dream company.
A few months ago, four months ago, I moved to San Francisco.

And one of those initiatives is to build the Vibe Studio.
And the Vibe Studio is a mixture of hardware.

And if we wanted to create a video where we're all like three, like we compete against each other to see who can vibe code the coolest app.
I think that style of video is really fun.
And so I wanted to create a podcast studio that is both high quality and it has the flexibility to do a lot of screen sharing.
Why did I want to do screen sharing?
Well, the biggest inspiration, I don't think people would be surprised by this, is Greg Eisenberg.
So Greg Eisenberg has the Startup Ideas podcast, and it is one of the fastest growing podcasts in business, or at least it was last year.
I'm not familiar with how fast it's growing now, but I will say it is a new phenomenon, and it is something that I'm calling a demo cast.
I think people are a little bit bored and tired of listening to people talk in podcasts.
Maybe they're not tired of it because the podcast market is growing so fast and less and less people are making podcasts, right?
The growth rate of people who are making podcasts is actually going down.
Meanwhile, the amount of eyeballs on podcasts are going up.
The appetite for long-form content is there.
It's just it's very winner take all.
It's not like short form where anyone can go viral.
A lot of the people who are into podcasts watch and listen to the same podcasts.
And I say watch because they're becoming more visual.
If you look at the long-form trends, right?
People are watching YouTube videos on their TV, and it's becoming a replacement for Netflix, and I think that's very interesting, and so I think we're seeing a rise of like more visual podcasts, and people are getting tired of like the same pseudo philosophical Chris Williamson style podcasts where they just kind of like talk about philosophy but not like really, and I think people want tactical strategies to learn how to use specific tools and actually learn, right?
They don't want to just listen to two people talk about how AI is changing the world.

And if we can build a team, right, if we can build a system and a place where we can safely record things and and um make content where all they have to do is show up like it's a consulting call, then we can grow rapidly, and we can build the personal brands of every person in the company.
